title: FirstFT: Today's top stories
text:
A frenzied battle between amateur investors and hedge funds generated the busiest trading day for US stock markets on record on Wednesday, with more than 23bn shares changing hands.

Day traders, organising on Reddit message boards, have targeted specific short sellers and attempted to inflict losses by piling into stocks against which they have bet. Among the funds that have suffered is Melvin Capital, run by former Steve Cohen protégé Gabe Plotkin. 

Hedge funds have scaled back the size of their stock market bets in recent days and professional investors are rethinking their strategies to contend with the growing influence of retail traders.

The “short squeeze”, which started on Wall Street, swept around the world on Wednesday, triggering big upward moves for some previously unloved companies. The gains stood in contrast to a broad market decline, with the S&P 500 index suffering its steepest drop since October.

The spectacular melt-up in shares has demonstrated the power of this group to fire up stocks — often to levels that professionals consider disconnected from reality, writes Katie Martin. Read more coverage in our Runaway Markets series. (FT)

Coronavirus digest

  • Americans will be able to enrol in new government-backed health insurance plans from February until May, as part of a move by the Biden administration to improve healthcare coverage during the coronavirus pandemic. Anthony Fauci said the US vaccine rollout needed to prioritise people of colour.

  • High level emergency talks between the EU and AstraZeneca on Wednesday night failed to end a crisis over coronavirus vaccine supplies.

  • The pandemic, a severe recession and the resignation of Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte has cast a shadow over Italy's plans to relaunch the economy. Spain's Madrid region will stop vaccinations for at least 10 days after supplies ran scarce.

  • Philippine president Rodrigo Duterte maintains firm support despite mishandling of Covid-19. The International Olympic Committee said it was “committed to the successful and safe” summer games in Tokyo.

  • The IMF has warned that emerging markets' limited access to vaccines poses a risk to global financial stability.

  • Lebanon's case surge is devastating a state hobbled by a financial crisis. (FT, BBC, Axios)

Keep up to date with the vaccine rollout with our recently launched tracker.

In the news

US tech earnings Apple reported its highest-ever net profit, with fourth-quarter revenues swelling to $111.4bn, driven by a 57 per cent rise in sales in greater China. Facebook delivered record quarterly revenues as the push into ecommerce bore fruit and electric carmaker Tesla reported results that topped Wall Street's expectations for revenue growth but failed to hit forecasts for earnings. (FT)

Powell: ‘We have not won this yet' After a two-day meeting, the Federal Reserve held its main interest rate close to zero and asset purchases steady as chairman Jay Powell warned that the battle against the economic fallout from the pandemic was far from over. (FT)

Biden suspends arms sales to Saudi Arabia and UAE The White House has suspended arms sales agreed by Donald Trump to Gulf allies Saudi Arabia and UAE. It is the first significant move by President Joe Biden to reset US relations with Sunni Arab regimes heavily courted by his predecessor. (FT)

US warns of heightened risk of attacks by domestic extremists The Department of Homeland Security warned on Wednesday of the risk of attacks by “ideologically-motivated violent extremists” on US soil. Federal prosecutors indicted three people associated with the Oath Keepers, a paramilitary organisation, for conspiring to obstruct Congress during the storming of the Capitol on January 6. (FT)

Walgreens Boots Alliance recruits new chief The drugstore group is to become the only company in the S&P 500 to be run by a black woman after it appointed Starbucks chief operating officer Roz Brewer as chief executive. (FT)

Boeing delays 777X deliveries again as it posts record annual loss The aerospace manufacturer delayed the entry of its wide-body 777X jet into commercial service by another year and posted a record net loss of nearly $12bn for 2020, even as it began delivering the 737 Max to customers last month. (FT)

Brazil's economic dilemma After unleashing a massive stimulus package to combat the effects of coronavirus, Brazil's public debt has soared — and investors are getting jittery. (FT)

The day ahead

Economic data US gross domestic product for the final quarter is out on Thursday; economists do not expect it to be as strong as the previous quarter after fiscal support waned and the labour market lost steam. Initial jobless claims are forecast to fall to 875,000. (WSJ, FT)

Earnings round-up American Airlines Group and Southwest Airlines are among the US companies reporting results on Thursday. Others include fast-food chain McDonalds and credit card providers Mastercard and Visa. (FT)

Sundance Film Festival The annual film festival, which usually takes place in Park City, Utah, will kick off Thursday with a virtual format. Check out our list of six films to watch this week. (Rolling Stone, FT)

Johnson travels to Scotland The British prime minister will visit Scotland on Thursday in an effort to stem support for independence. Robert Shrimsley says there is no cunning wheeze in the British government to stop independence. (FT)

What else we're reading

Can Biden usher in a higher minimum wage? Since taking office, Joe Biden has pushed to increase the federal minimum wage, which has been stuck at $7.25 per hour since 2009. Tying the drive to his $1.9tn economic stimulus package fulfils one of his election pledges. But it risks complicating the quick passage of the stimulus bill. (FT)

The future of Trumpism Recently-elected lawmakers such as Marjorie Taylor Greene and Lauren Boebert are determined to demonstrate their loyalty to the former president. But their real power lies in an ability to command the narrative, rather than notching up bona fide political victories. (FT)

Jane Street: the leading Wall Street firm ‘no one's' heard of Jane Street may be little known outside its community. But the company has become one of the world's largest market-makers, trading more than $17tn worth of securities in 2020. The fast-growing firm helped keep bond ETFs liquid last year amid growing risk to US debt during Covid-19. (FT)

McKinsey's call for political neutrality only serves Putin “Stay safe, stay neutral, enjoy weekend,” a McKinsey managing partner wrote to staff in Russia on Friday. The management consultancy's attempt to ban employees from attending protests in support of Alexei Navalny helped maintain the status quo, writes Henry Foy. (FT)

How cities around the world are tackling climate change The FT spoke to four mayors and asked them to explain what they are doing to tackle climate change. From replanting in Los Angeles to increasing water table levels in Mumbai, greening open spaces in Accra and promoting “active travel” in Paris. Watch the video here. (FT)

Sports leagues should join forces with streamers There are ways to make streaming live sport a viable business, argues global media editor Alex Barker. Netflix, for example, could buy a league or just create one from scratch, he says. (FT)

Podcast of the day

António Guterres on the UN in a fractured world Covid-19, climate change and peacekeeping are all 2021 priorities for the UN. But these challenges require multilateral solutions. Gideon Rachman talks to the UN secretary-general about bridging security and military divides. (FT)
